39149143.review:
Opus Magum n'est pas dans son concept aussi synthétiquement parfait que l'indépassable SpaceChem. Pendant de cet aboutissement moindre, un concept plus simple, plus lisible et abordable.
Il permet donc à un joueur éventuellement refroidit par l'austérité résultant de la perfection synthétique d'un SpaceChem (où zones d’instructions et d’exécution étaient confondues) de gouter à la joie spécifique qu'offrent les jeux ZachTronics où le joueur n'est soumis qu'à une unique et simple stimulation: la gratification.
Aucune frustration, aucune sanction, le joueur est toujours gagnant, récompensé. La raison: l'objet n'est pas strictement de résoudre des puzzles, cet objectif facilement atteignable induisant pourtant déjà une satisfaction (on produit une solution et on observe en démiurge sa créature mécanique dans l'accomplissement de son oeuvre)  ; mais de les résoudre au mieux possible.  Le mieux, bien que définit pourtant par des indicateurs comptables stricts (coût, cycles, zone), étant ressenti par le joueur, c'est le miracle des concepts Zachtronics, comme le plus élégant.
Quête d'élégance donc et de perfection qui produit un satisfaction croissante jusqu'à la jubiltation lorsque l’artisan-joueur produit une mécanique qu’il ressent comme parfaite (chef-d'oeuvre qu'il pourra immortaliser et partager en vidéo).  
La douceur de cette quête n'est pas étrangère au principe de classement unique qui fait loi chez Zachtronics : un classement par répartition par tranches. Ce flou (on ne saura jamais si l'on a LA meilleure solution, on pourra se bercer de cette douce illusion, mais uniquement qu'on fait partie du groupe toujours plus restreints des artisans les plus élégants) induit ce qu'il faut de stimulation sans livrer le joueur à la frustration et à l'épuisement d'une quète obsessionelle pour LA première place au classement. Très sain. La vraie joie de vaincre (se vaincre soi-même, ou plutôt, se dépasser) sans les désagrément de la défaite.

Opus Magnum est à l'oeil le produit le plus élégant développé par Zachtronics. Sans se départir parfois du charme singulier, un peu désuet qui fait la marque de l'enseigne, il y a cette fois une volonté claire d'aboutir visuellement à quelque chose de certes simple, mais élégant et engageant. Zachtronics sort de sa démarche à tendance nerd  ou autistique pour faire de l'oeil à une audience plus large.
Reste quelques écueils d’ergonomie qui rendent le voyage un peu plus laborieux qu’il ne devrait l'être :
[*] comme toujours, pas de raccourci en menu contextuel (sans utiliser conjointement les raccourcis clavier, l'édition est tout de même laborieuse).
[*] pas de fonction de décalage globale d’instruction par insertion (qu'il faut compenser par manipulations fastidieuses).
[*] rotation impossible d'un ensemble d'éléments (là aussi très fastidieux lorsqu'on réalise qu'une partie du mécanisme n'est pas bien orienté pour s'agencer avec le reste)
[*] pas de possibilité de se déplacer en marche arrière en pas à pas (pour analyser les mouvements en amont d’un problème)
[*] pas de possibilité d'étendre la zone d'édition pour visualiser plus de 6 lignes d'instructions
[*] pas de possiblité de mettre des marqueurs ou repères visuels (couleur) pour identifier facilement un groupe d'instructions dont on sait  qu'il sera amené à être copié-collé.(il faut parfois jouer les séquences au pas à pas pour les identifier avec certitudes).
[*] pas de mode plein écran pour visualiser en phase d'exécution une mécanique dont la zone dépasse celle de la fenêtre d'édition.
[*] dans la liste des puzzles, aucun indicateur permettant d'identifier rapidement un puzzle, et encore moins un puzzle pour lequel on n’aurait renoncé temporairement à atteindre l'objectif ultime d'être parmi les plus élégants des artisans selon chaque critère.
[*] pas de classification automatique des solutions trouvées selon les critères zone/coût/cycle. Ce qui contraint à les caractériser laborieusement manuellement dans leur nom.


Mais ces points font détails et n’entachent en rien le fait qu'Opus Magnum est un jeu passionnant qui procure un plaisir constant, beaucoup de gratification, et dont la durée de vie est énorme (cf le workshop). Au terme duquel le joueur flatté pourrait bien être tenté de poursuivre le voyage vers SpaceChem, accomplissement ultime de Zachtronics qui mériterait une ré-édition (d’autant qu’il ne fonctionne plus sur les dernières versions d’OS X).

A good game. Not worth 20 dollars. I'd place it at 10 dollars but if you're desperate for a new programming puzzler It's worth it.

The puzzles are programmed with tape on a hexagonal field. This is a very limited game because of this. Looping and control structures are extremely limited, to the point of being almost non existent. This means that your instructions will frequently be quite drawn out. It takes awhile to produce solutions for the larger puzzles and this isn't because they are difficult. The puzzles in this game never really get particularly difficult. It's the easiest zachtronics game. The nature of the game can make it take awhile to solve large puzzles, but doesn't allow for the puzzles to be hard. Even when the play field is constrained it's never that much of a brain bender. Of course, if you play for optomization I'm sure you can find plenty of challenge.

Here's the thing: being an easier, less difficult game isn't a bad thing. If you play this expecting to be driven to insanity over mindbenders you're going to be dissapointed. If you play this to relax and zone out it's quite good. Turn off the background music, play something low key and just toy around with puzzles. They're still satisfying to solve because they take quite a bit of tinkering to function just right and it's fun to watch your solutions in motion. It's a good game, but because of limits inherent to the game itself it feels a bit overpriced at the moment.

[u]What I liked: [/u]
[list]
    [*]Yet another masterpiece from Zach
    [*]Simplest game yet
    [*]Increasing difficulty of puzzle designs

[/list]
[u]What You Need to Know: [/u]
[list]
    [*]If you’ve never played a Zachtronics game before this is the easiest to understand and should start with this game. If you’re a hardcore fan this game does limit what you can do compared to their previous games.

    [*]First the game has a story that I completely skipped because who plays these game for stories. If you want a reason for what you’re doing the game does that with each puzzle correlating with what’s happening in the story. 

    [*]Now the meat of the game, you do have open ended puzzles that you get with all Zachtronics’ games with the easiest intro into their games for newer people. You don’t have to worry about syncing issues as the solution will make all items pad to the same time. This will make your solution slow but allows those that might struggle get a solution out instead of dealing with timings. You can still tweak it and make assembly line or anything that previous games could but with the new restrictions you can’t change.

    [*]The game is hex based instead of usually grid which means that rotating at different distances doesn’t move items equally, but can be used to move items quicker if needed. The solution is fixed and can be rotated but not mirrored so you can waste time thinking your solution is good to only have it facing the wrong way. I don’t remember if this was an issue in SpaceChem. The dumbest thing they didn’t keep was debugging, you can’t back step or add a function to stop right before a known issue so you can try and figure it out like previous games. This really makes it annoying to always having to replay and wait to pause right before the error and not have the ability to cycle backward or forward. I don’t understand why this was not added.

    [*]Your move sets are on a pictogram full of as many lines for each arm or piston that allow you to copy, move and rotate your whole solution and any part in-between along with the pictogram version of your solution if you need to quickly change any aspect of a mistake or redesign. This simple UI is so good. If you learn the hotkeys you can punch solutions out fast and rework with such ease. This design is great and hope to see in future titles.

    [*]Once you beat the game you get 10 insanely limited space puzzles that will please those that love the most minimal area designing of solutions. Personally I don’t care much for those. You also have an atom matching minigame that is optional that is a good timewaster like minesweeper or solitaire that would be good as a separate game for those that love playing these games at work. These are randomly generated and do require some thought as you can lock yourself into a loss and be forced to start a new game. You do get more story if you play enough of these, again I didn’t care so I didn’t do many of them. Just to see what this minigame was all about.

    [*]Overall the game is a great addition to the Zachtronics’ style game with it being only second to Infinifactory. I beat this game unlike SpaceChem so I already like it more. It’s easier to get into yet puzzles that are still just as great and some that are hard. But nothing totally like the complexity near the end of SpaceChem. The ease of creating solutions and being able to quickly edit them is a great thing even with the annoyance of no back stepping. This is the best starting point unless they release more in the future that make it even easier to play

39013123.review:
Very nice-looking game.
Unfortunately, this is the only positive moment I found here.

Every time I'm trying to play it, I find myself thinking "in SpaceChem it was better". 

Hexagonal field is ok, it requires a significant mindshift, and it's interesting. But everything else... 

SpaceChem was a puzzle – the requirement was to assemble complex molecules in very limited space. 
Opus Magnum is totally casual – field is endless, so just put more manipulators and other stuff, if you need. Game doesn't make a challenge for you. Seeing other player's incredible super-minimalistic solutions is not a real motivation.

Instead, Opus Magnum introduces own, totally artifical restirctions. 

First, shape of molecula matters now: proper bounds between proper atoms are not enough, now you must properly rotate them also. As result, often you have to rebuild your completely working solution because two atoms are connected under wrong angle. 

Second – alchemical tools are very inconvenient. Join 3 atoms in a row – so primitive task, but here you'll have to build some crazy machinery around, because atoms can be joined either one by one, or 4 at once but under 120deg angle. 

Both of these restrictions are not looking reasonable. They are annoying. Nobody even tries to explain why angles are so important in alchemy world, or why noone invented simple binding glyph for 3 atoms in a row. There is a difference between solving a puzzle and fighting a game inconvenience, and Opus Magnum doesn't understand it, unfortunately.

In SpaceChem you opened new advanced tools with a time (often accordingly to storyline), so it was a sense of progress in the game. You was interested to play further to find more content and much more interesting puzzles.
In Opus Magnum you immediately have access to everything you may ever need – except of a few very very special tools, available only in special levels (I saw 3 of them so far). No progress, nothing new – just again and again build the same overcomplicated machines for primitive tasks. Booooooring.

Finally, in SpaceChem there was a storyline – and gods, it was amazing. I won't even say about unique "boss fight" levels – just story itself. Pieces of exposition, describing locations, characters, situations, feelings and actions – it was like a real book, and I greedily solved puzzles one by one just to read next chapter.
And in Opus Magnum... well... we have that dialogs between levels. That soooooooooo interesting dialogs about love potion for old duke and about exiting of making an super-lightweight alhemist's rope. Dialogs, full of empty meaningless phrases, imitating a real communication. I can't say without swearing how boring and useless that dialogs are. 90% of phrases can be completely removed from the game and nothing will change. It's an epic fail. 

As conclusion. I'll repeat myself: SpaceChem was a hard and interesting puzzle game; Opus Magnum is a nice-looking casual time-killer. 
I see no reasons to spend money on Opus Magnum – better go play SpaceChem if you didn't.

[h1]Quelle déception ![/h1]

L'histoire qui accompagne le jeu est d'une platitude exaspérante... On fini par zapper les phases de discussion pour en arriver directement à la partie puzzle. J'ai du mal à croire qu'un studio expérimenté puisse se planter à ce point sur la naration et les personnages. Pourtant le potentiel est là, cet univers d'alchimistes aurait pu donner quelquechose d'unique, avec de vrais enjeux, et pourquoi pas laisser au joueur la possibilité de faire des choix pour l'avenir de sa maison par exemple. Histoire gachée.

La mécanique de puzzle est excellente, on est sur du déjà vu dans un esprit Spacechem totalement maitrisé. Malgré tout, ca sent la repompe sans amélioration. Il manque clairement quelques outils pour copier, cloner, remplacer des modèles de bras en gardant la partition, faire tourner des groupes d'objets ensembles... Difficile à accepter pour un studio qui a fait ses preuves dans le genre depuis plusieurs années. Zachtronics n'a rien capitalisé de son expérience, Opus Magnum pourrait être leur premier jeu.

Pour ce qui est du défit, mon sentiment est partagé. J'ai l'impression d'avoir le pouvoir de faire de grandes choses, mais qu'on me demande de produire de l'eau salée. Il faudra attendre assez longtemps dans la campagne pour accéder à des puzzles plus motivants. C'est une regression par rapport à Spacechem.

Pour le reste, les musiques sont minimalistes, seulement 4 succès à débloquer, l'ui est décevente, le tuto pas très clair.

Zachtronics aurait pu faire un effort et nous proposer largement mieux quand ont sait qu'ils maitrisent déjà la partie puzzle repompée à 75% sur Spacechem.

38978361.review:
I recommend this game as another wonderful addition to the Zachtronics puzzler library, but I find myself liking classic Space Chem more than Opus Magnum.

As a SpaceChem veteran I'm a little disappointed by the length of the campaign; finished it in just under 10 hours. As with every zachtronics game there is still a bevy of additional content to tackle after the main campaign, and with user created content you're never really finished.

However the campaign is a lot easier to get through for newcomers to the genre, which I think is a good change compared to the rather difficult space-chem campaign.

I think there could have been more 'mini-challenges' to the campaign where you are limited in one specific way, causing players to brainstorm alternative strategies to do things, instead it seems the campaign is all about making bigger and bigger products, often with smaller and more basic reagents, leading to some painfully long programs, while not particularly complicated.

Management of these really long programs is quite a chore; made a little bit easier if you read the controls for selecting and copying. Sadly there seems no simple way to store a copy in a clipboard, it must be placed somewhere in the instruction set, which can get confusing.

Final Verdict; absolutely worth the value but you may end up liking SpaceChem more.

38944432.review:
Opus Magnum, a puzzle game where your creativity is just as valuable as your ablitity to calculate. 

TL;DR: Worth full asking price, Opus Magnum is an amazing title that inspires the engineer, artist and alchemist within us all. 9/10 

Prior titles from Zachtronics, such as TIS-100 and Shenzen I/O, were a blast, but through the rigidity that is inherent in the environment of both titles (via the limitations of assembly programming/computer science principles), creativity is sacrificed and you must force yourself to see solutions that are appropriate within the context of the games logical limitation(s).

PROS:
+ This is where Opus Magnum really shines and easily becomes the most accessible title from Zachtronics. You aren't simply given a manual and then 'stuck' within certain low-level logic operations (transistors, logic gates, binary manipulation, registers, etc.) guiding your design decisions.
+ In Opus Magnum, you aren't looking for THEE solution, you are given the freedom to invent ANY solution that assembles the necessary output (product) from the originally provided reagents. 
+ Opus Magnum is a beautiful visual representation of algorithms. Algorithm being defined as :  A finite set of unambiguous instructions that, given some set of initial conditions, can be performed in a prescribed sequence to achieve a certain goal and that has a recognizable set of end conditions.
+ The pool of 12 instructions that is utilized when 'programming' life into your various alchemy related mechanisms is elegant and effecient. Not having to actually write these instructions, but merely snap them into the timeline, births the freedom of creativity I was mentioning earlier.

CONS:
- WHY IS THERE NO 'BACK' (<--) BUTTON after automating the system? You have stop, step, and play, but when debugging, a simple back button would work wonders! Especially on longer solutions where your code (instructions) run for a considerable amount of time before reaching the appropriate section you wish to alter.
If you don't pause the cycling of your machine prior to this section of interest, you will have to run it again, from the beginning, and 'catch' the spot you want to edit.

Fun, but the offline, unplugged experience is bad, and the save mechanics are downright maddening. I would still recommend this game because the following won't apply to most users, but if you intend to play on a laptop or iterate on level solutions, beware.

The core concept of this game -- programming alchemical machines to build products -- is fun and well-executed. The levels are challenging and feel well-paced. The game's artwork is gorgeous and immersive. Almost all the goodwill earned by those things is wiped away by a variety of small irritants that added together degrade the experience.

Let's start with performance. This game uses CPU like it's mining bitcoin. It's not at all clear what in the game is so expensive, but whatever it is drives the "play-on-battery" life of this game down into "maybe an hour or so" territory. That's considerably worse than more performant alternatives in this space (e.g. Factorio) and makes it difficult to play what should be a resource-friendly puzzler on an unplugged laptop.

Of course, if you're unplugged, you might also not have Internet access. That's fine -- the game still runs -- but your friends' records aren't cached locally. If you were aiming to compete with one of them you'd best maintain a connection from time-to-time, which sounds easy in theory but results in multiple Steam restarts in practice, given Steam's inability to transition on- or offline cleanly.

Finally, the game lacks a "exit but don't save" function and its absence is totally baffling. Suppose you're hard at work trying to hit a particular goal on a level -- M cycles, N area, whatever -- and you try a new design that's worse than your previous one. You have no ability, as a player, to exit the machine *without* saving your progress. If you want to design iterative solutions you need a new solution for each iteration or the ability to reconstruct your previous iteration from memory. It's an infuriating flaw in the save mechanic and is unfortunate because the game otherwise goes out of its way to preserve your work, even when you don't want it to.

This is great. Unlike a couple other Zachtronics games, this one doesn't really require you to rtfm and learn new syntax. So I'd say it’s certainly more accessible. 39582797.review:
Opus Magnum 确实是 Zachtronics 最友好的一款解谜游戏了。

与Z社的前几部“硬核”解谜作品相比，Opus 没有太空化学里那一整页一整页的剧情说明文本，也没有 TIS-100 和 SHENZHEN I/O 里那几十页的pdf教程手册。相比于枯燥的电路板和单调的类命令行界面，Opus 精美的画面也更吸引人眼球。再加上游戏初期完整的教程引导，种种因素让我在通关之后仍感到意犹未尽。

本作解决方案的设计是以机械臂移动“弹珠”为核心的，因此如果仅仅从通关的目的来说，难度甚至过于简单了，尤其是和上面提到的Z社其它几部作品相比。由于全部的主线谜题都没有空间、成本和区域限制，对于大部分关卡来说，所有的流程其实就是在让你用一种“语言”去描述一个用原料来“拼装”产物的过程,基本概括一下就是用机械臂来移动、旋转和键合原子。在这种情况下，流程的设计思路就变得十分简单，一般只要分析好产物结构和合成顺序即可，这个过程中唯一的难点，也只是后期产物复杂以后容易出现的空间冲突了。

因此本作的乐趣还是在优化设计这个过程中。而驱动玩家不断优化设计的一大动力就是Z社游戏传统的社区/好友排行榜。三个优化的方向分别是成本、周期数（效率）和占用空间。成本的优化需要对产物的合成流程有非常清晰的认识；周期和空间的优化是一个时空权衡的问题。如上所述，游戏前期的难度比较简单，优化周期时基本只需要无脑堆料就可以了，因为游戏的循环同步机制也比较简单粗暴，最大循环直接就是自动按照最长的操作流程来的，因此瓶颈很容易判断。中后期由于更加复杂的产物和刁钻的原料，需要更多地考虑平衡、并行的问题，以及后期很容易出现的机械臂碰撞冲突。从这里看，难度曲线也是比较合理的。

程序员也许比较容易对Z社游戏有特殊的好感，不过很惭愧也很遗憾（？）的是，Opus 是我通关的第一款Z社游戏...。其它的不是摸了就是开了坑还没填。而这其中的原因，除了友好的游戏性之外，还因为 Opus 拥有精致的美术、音效设计，以及比较吸引我的剧情。一颗颗金莹剔透的原子玻璃球整齐地摆放在六角棋盘构成的“嬗变引擎”上，配合浑然一体的UI，视觉上就让人很舒服。原子的抓取、键合，机械臂的旋转、释放等操作都拥有精美的音效，特别是火元素，三种不同的键合拥有三种不同音色音调的声音。我猜如果游戏的影响力足够大，玩家足够多的话，甚至会有人用特别设计的操作流程中的音效来奏曲吧。

游戏的剧情也由十分友好的对话形式推进，简单又风趣的文本讲述了一位炼金术士的人生沉浮（。）虽然 Opus 中的炼金术是如此的扯淡，但是谜题与剧情是完全契合的，比如剧情需要主角制作一些极黑的线作为一种服装材料，在谜题中，玩家要生产的产物就需要由铁原子和盐原子无限连接结合以制得。（科学的力量真伟大！

此外，游戏中还加入了同样以炼金原子为元素的小游戏：西格玛的花园，玩法类似 Mahjong Solitaire 之类的一款配对消除游戏。略带毒性，以至于我抽空写了一个 Web 版本的[url=https://chesterz184.github.io/sigmar-garden/]西格玛的花园[/url]以便随时游玩，顺便适配了下手机（卜兼容卜要找窝），并且尽力还原了游戏里的图形效果。[spoiler]很遗憾的是，等我写完的时候已经不想再去玩它了（？？？）[/spoiler]

至于不足之处，我是一直不知道如何同时旋转一组部件..设计流程时候的操作还有不少优化的空间。以及，主线内容没有设计限制的设定也可能会让一些玩家失去游戏的动力。还有就是Z社睿智不用心的成就设计，对成奴不友好（？）

但是不管如何，Opus Magnum 的高素质还是非常值得解谜爱好者，以及没有接触过 Zachtronics 游戏的新玩家去尝试的。这也让我更加期待 Zachtronics 的下一款作品~

It would be nice if the timeline at the bottom where players compose instructions for the alchemy engine had ONE of the following features:

A:  an advertised hard limit, letting players know they cannot place more instructions beyond a certain point

- or -

B:  scroll bars allowing the player to navigate around the timeline

It is still a very enjoyable and relaxing game.

Haven't played any of the dev's previous titles; so, this type of puzzle game is new to me. I went in with an open mind...and did not regret the purchase one bit. I'm a chemist in my other life; so, the pseudo-chemistry of alchemy was engaging, and had a bit of foundation in fact...reminded me a bit of my undergrad Organic Chemistry's lab lessons on modeling stereoisomers (molecules of the same mass oriented differently in 3 dimensions), albeit this game was a bit more sophisticated with its virtual manipulation versus my experience with the sticks and balls by which we used to build the 3-D structures by hand. 

Anyhow, my point is, the game is a learning experience while, at the same time, being quite enjoyable. I actually recommended the game to a colleague who is in charge of internal training in Six Sigma for possible use as a training module. While it's a game for entertainment, it also exercises attributes of lean manufacturing, as the mechanism that you build is ultimately ranked in terms of its overall efficiency using histograms to illustrate your performance in terms of cost, size and time.

I would highly recommend this to anyone who loves to explore his/her creative side, enjoys moderately challenging puzzles and paces his/her gaming in spurts rather than one, long playthrough. I would qualify myself as an intermediate gamer who enjoys the long plays over many genres; but, can also enjoy a game that can be iteratively approached, letting the experience soak in over time, taking 1-3 puzzles in a sitting. I've seen others on here criticize the $20USD price; I disagree - the price seems fair. Going back to my aforementioned observation regarding modeling in academics - software used in kinetic and structural modeling can cost hundreds to thousands of USD; although this is a game with a watered down version of mechanics one would encounter in the more sophisticated software, the game is deserving of the price as it uses some of the same key elements.

Would highly recommend!

My first thought, after playing a few hours: any elementary school that wants to produce budding engineers or programmers should buy a few copies of OM. The fun of the game will wake up a sleeping ability for those things.

A suggestion: add this concept to an adventure game and you will have something revolutionary. Make sure the adventure is great, though. Otherwise it will only be about the puzzle game.

Who wouldn't love a game like Neverwinter Nights where you would get magical recipes, find/buy ingredients and use an alchemical machine to come up with explosive spells and items - cost depending on how well you set up the works? If you, instead of working your way through minor bosses, could find another path - or several - where you roam the countryside looking for ingredients and  completing minor tasks to come back later to blow the Big Boss sky high at one go? And on to the next city, or back to defeating the minor bosses just as an afterthought. 

This would work as an addition in a warfare game just as well. Imagine a Total War game - a bit simplified one, perhaps - where you could use your alchemical skills to get better weapons for your crack troops, for instance. You would have to conquer a lead mine extra swift - and if you could add to it a Spring of Quintessence you gained through a deal with the Elves, you would have REALLY sharp swords dealing elemental damage and armor that can deal with almost any elemental damage. Spending money on a large alchemy machine is possible, but if you're ingenious you can let it run for a bit longer with cheaper bits, and if you're really patient you can fit it in a smaller package, make it do the work in 2/3 of the time and save some money on the side. Better chance your defenses will last long enough.

Or you could buy the steel from the Dwarves, conquer the Spring of Quintessence, build up that salt mine in the sticks while conquering the town where they make Van Berlo wheels. 

In such a game the battles could well be the old-fashioned turn based hex board battles just as well. It would be entertaining enough. I paid 20 for this, I would easily pay 40 for that. If the map, diplomacy and the rest were on par with more recent games, of course.

Add this to Endless Legend, for instance. Buy an expensive hero who can work alchemy. Suddenly your dust reserves will be inexhaustible - for as long as you have access to Hyperium. The Roving Clans will, of course, deny your access to the markets. Your dust reserve is worthless, all of a sudden. Crap. Should have dealt with the clans first. Wait! I can still work crossbow bolts that deal 5 times the damage they normally do. I do have plenty of titanium in reserve. Better get moving, clans. Someone else has an alchemist who can make bolts 6 times more powerful? I will have to readjust the engine. Maybe add another element to the equation? HEY! I gathered 100.000 dust before the Clans got wind of my plans! I will turn 80% of it into Blitzkrieg grade Antimorphiunium by bonding it with titanium and what little Hyperium I have. I will get impregnable armor, spells aside. The clans are in trouble.

Of course this extra mechanism - in any game - would have to be a trump that only one or two factions have, and others would have to have something to counter it somehow. Otherwise everyone would play the same way. 

I really warmed up to the subject there. I hope someone else does, too. I would love to see game mechanics evolve far beyond the current ones, and this kind of puzzle thing might be a start. Some adventure games do have puzzles already, but they're mostly more annoying than fun. Opus Magnum puzzles have the great advantage of having multiple solutions. That's key to anything inspiring.

There are countless ways to solve each puzzle, but the story doesn't force you to stick to any constraints. So, you can solve just about every puzzle by making a big, monstrosity of a program that costs a lot of gold, takes a lot of cycles, and takes up a lot of area on the board.


IF ONLY they had added a constraint to each mission (The headmaster require you to create a stamina potion with only 130 gold, for example), each solved puzzle would have been just a little more frustrating as you try to figure out a way to beat the constraints, and that much satifying when you solve the puzzle. I personally am not the type to do missions again and again just to tickle my own fancy and see if I can get it smaller.


Even still, it's an incredible game but it would have been and a 9 or a 10 had each mission force you to stick to certain rules. 


Recommended, even for those who don't typically like puzzle games.

The short: Is it worth $20? Absolutely. Past the main game, there's easily dozens of hours of more possibly gameplay, thanks to the Workshop. However, there's some pretty apparent downfalls to this game that make optimizing solutions needlessly difficult.

Further explanation: The inability to change the zoom level is an obvious picking point, especially when playing on a screen that only does 1280x720. Contraptions can and will go easily past the edge of the screen, and having to constantly "fast-forward" to a specific point to watch and rewatch what goes on in order to "debug" your solution is annoying. 
In addition, the lack of any number labels to the timeline and inability to write notes within the timeline result in a lot of pointless confusion. 
So between all of that, a few other minor points, optimizing for anything but steps (to completion) a mental struggle; note that I used "struggle" and not "challenge" since a lot of the optimization part of gameplay is stuff like having to search around for a part whose number is hidden under the arm of another part, having to keep a mental log of what number parts are in a group, and trying to remember the significance of a chunk of the 200+ commands you have on one arm...

Overall though, definitely a 3.75/5 game.
